newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX crude oil ends week lower on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX crude oil ends week lower on profit-taking.

text.p: NYMEX crude oil prices ended the week lower on profit taking which accelerated after three crude ports in Mexico were re-opened after being shut down due to a hurricane, traders said.

"We had a bounce yesterday, and traders just lightened their positions ahead of the weekend. The Mexican news that was helping to support was taken out," said Tom Bentz, a trader with ING Derivatives.
October crude settled 34 cents lower to $21.96 a barrel. The near-term support level for October crude was pegged by Bentz at $21.85 to $21.90.
Mexico's state-owned oil company Petroleos Mexicanos re-opened all three of its crude ports after shutting them down for two days due to Hurricane Dolly.
Market sources estimated the ports export 1.5 million barrels daily.
Traders said Friday's expiry of September refined product options drove prices of the underlying months down around the strike prices.
September heating oil closed 0.49 cent lower at 61.99 cents a gallon, and September unleaded gasoline closed off 0.66 cent to 63.22 cents a gallon.
Traders said they expect heating oil prices to rebound on Monday due to inventories currently being at historical lows.
Traders said the tight stocks have created an unusual backwardation in August for heating oil, where the front months are more expensive than the back months.
Usually in August, heating oil contracts are in contango, with the later months carrying a higher price reflecting increasing demand as the winter nears.
September heating oil closed Friday 0.66 cent a gallon above the January contract.
-- Harry Milling, New York Energy Desk, +1 212-959-1761
